results.title: Athens Is Only Getting Hotter. Its New ‘Chief Heat Officer’ Hopes to Cool It Down.
results.abstract: Eleni Myrivili has been tasked with finding ways to help the Greek capital cope with ever-hotter heat waves that are expected to be part of life for years to come.

multimedia.caption: “Heat is an invisible and insidious killer,” said Eleni Myrivili, Athens’ new “chief heat officer.”

results.title: America’s Afghan War: A Defeat Foretold?
results.abstract: Recent history suggests that it is foolish for Western powers to fight wars in other people’s lands and that the U.S. intervention was almost certainly doomed from the start.

results.title: He Guarded Haiti’s Slain President. And He’s the Target of a Drug Inquiry.
results.abstract: Officials are examining whether President Jovenel Moïse’s killing was tied to the drug trade. The man in charge of his safety was a suspect in a major trafficking case, they say.

results.title: How the Taliban Turned Social Media Into a Tool for Control
results.abstract: In the 1990s, they banned the internet. Now they use it to threaten and cajole the Afghan people, in a sign of how they might use technology to build power.

results.title: ‘Super Taster’ Who Lost Sense of Smell Is Helping Italians Regain It
results.abstract: A celebrated epicure in Italy was devastated when Covid-19 first stole, then warped his sense of taste. Through training, Michele Crippa has recaptured some of it and is now on a quest to aid others.

multimedia.caption: Michele Crippa, center, a celebrated gourmand in Italy, experienced a devastating loss because of Covid-19: his sense of smell.

results.title: As Chinese Vaccines Stumble, U.S. Finds New Opening in Asia
results.abstract: Several Southeast Asian nations are raising doubts about the efficacy of China’s vaccines. The Biden administration has recently offered to provide shots, “no strings attached.”
results.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Steven Lee Myers

multimedia.caption: Malaysia’s health minister said the country would stop using China’s Sinovac vaccine once its supply ran out. The AstraZeneca vaccine was used to vaccinate people in Kuala Lumpur in May.

results.title: The Polarized Publishing World
results.abstract: Political books can be fraught for big publishing houses, but the rewards often outweigh the risks.

results.title: Traveling to Hong Kong in the pandemic is hard. The government just made it harder.
results.abstract: Abrupt changes in quarantine rules have left Hong Kong residents apoplectic, especially after the actress Nicole Kidman, who is in the city to film a new Amazon series, was reported to have received an exemption.

multimedia.caption: Waiting for shuttle buses to mandatory government-designated quarantine hotels in the arrival hall at the Hong Kong International Airport on Tuesday.

results.title: On the ground: Kabul on edge.
results.abstract: A New York Times photographer chronicled a day in Kabul. It is a portrait of a city of contrasts, with tension sometimes breaking into the open and at other times bubbling beneath the hum of daily life.

results.title: 1946: Vatican Newspaper Denounces a Pistol Duel
results.abstract: The Osservatore Romano complained that the shootout between two Romans — despite leaving neither hurt — hinted at the societal ills that had flourished in postwar Italy.

results.title: In Rare Move, Japan Grants Asylum to Soccer Player From Myanmar
results.abstract: Ko Pyae Lyan Aung had defied the military junta’s rule at home after its coup, and had gambled he could win the right to stay in Japan.
results.byline: By Hisako Ueno and Ben Dooley
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: A small act of resistance by Ko Pyae Lyan Aung in Osaka, Japan, before a match triggered intense news coverage and brought concern that his life could be in danger if he returned home.

results.title: South Koreans Now Dislike China More Than They Dislike Japan
results.abstract: There is growing anti-China sentiment in South Korea, particularly among young voters. Conservative politicians are eager to turn the antipathy into a presidential election issue.

multimedia.caption: People in the streets of Seoul this month. Anti-Chinese sentiment has grown so much this year that China has replaced Japan as the most disliked nation by South Koreans.
multimedia.copyright: Simon Shin/SOPA Images, via LightRocket, via Getty Images
